p: Lymphopenia is commonly assessed in most viral infections, specifically, type A and B influenza [ 20]. According to a previous study, lymphopenia was also observed in SARS and MERS [ 21]. Coronavirus infection usually induces an immune response, resulting in decreased CD4 count and immunosuppression [ 22, 23]. Simultaneously, the virus also damages the epithelial walls, and disrupts surfactant in the airways, providing access to rapid bacterial growth and resulting in a secondary bacterial infection, adversely affecting immunosuppressed patients.
